title: Credit Suisse Looks to Reduce Ties to SoftBank-Backed Greensill Capital
summary: The Swiss bank has grown concerned about the speciality finance firm's exposure to a single client. LONDON- Credit Suisse Group AG is looking at ways to reduce ties to Greensill Capital over concerns about the specialty finance firm's exposure to a single client, U.K.-based steel magnate Sanjeev Gupta, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Iran Rejects Offer of Direct U.S. Nuclear Talks
summary: Rejection unlikely to kill off diplomacy but time seen running short ahead of Persian New Year, Iranian election. Iran rejected a European Union offer to hold direct nuclear talks with the U.S. in the coming days, risking renewed tension between Tehran and Western capitals.

title: Eighteen Killed in Myanmar's Bloodiest Day of Protests Since Coup
summary: Resume Subscription. SINGAPORE-At least 18 people were killed in Myanmar, the United Nations said, as security forces began their toughest crackdown yet against protesters who have taken to the streets for more than three weeks to oppose this month's coup, signaling the military's growing willingness to use lethal force despite international condemnation.

title: Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 Vaccine Gets Green Light From CDC
summary: The signoff marks the last step before wide use can begin this week; J&J's vaccine joins those by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention signed off on adding Johnson & Johnson 's newly authorized Covid-19 vaccine to the arsenal of preventive weapons against the coronavirus.

title: Voting Rights at the Supreme Court
summary: The Justices have a rare chance to clarify federal election law.. Election laws have become a dangerous political flashpoint, as Americans recently learned the hard way. On Tuesday the Supreme Court will hear a potentially landmark case (Brnovich v. DNC) that offers an opportunity to restore the Voting Rights Act to its original purpose.

title: Plan B for a $15 Minimum Wage
summary: It's not a mandate-it's a tax. At least that's Bernie Sanders's pitch.. As expected, the Senate's parliamentarian ruled last week that mandating a nationwide $15 minimum wage cannot be done via budget reconciliation, with a mere 51 votes. Some progressives, including some in Congress, are not eager to reconcile with this procedural flaw. "Replace the parliamentarian," Rep. Ilhan Omar tweeted. "This is unacceptable."

title: Erasing Hong Kong's Democrats
summary: China's agents charge nearly the entire opposition under a sedition law.. Hong Kong authorities moved this weekend to imprison nearly the entire opposition movement. The message is that anyone who runs as a pro-democracy candidate will be treated as a criminal.

title: McKinsey's Leadership Vote Reveals Cracks in Its Global Partnership
summary: Settlement on work with opioids makers prompted complaints from overseas partners; tension built over the firm's changes. On Feb. 4, McKinsey & Co. announced a $573 million settlement for its work with opioids makers. Kevin Sneader, the firm's top partner, personally apologized for McKinsey's behavior.

title: The CIA Can Help Spot the Next Pandemic
summary: Intel agencies and public-health officials need to work together against security risks like Covid.. In December 2019, unfamiliar and serious cases of pneumonia started to appear at hospitals in Wuhan, China. Doctors were stumped. They began sending off an unusually high number of samples to local labs for genomic sequencing to see if a new virus was lurking in patients' lung fluid. By the end of the month, there were clusters of these pneumonia infections in at least three separate families, an indication that a new virus was spreading among people.

title: Beyond Left and Right
summary: On the one hand, mixed dominance makes me who I am. On the other hand, I don't know how or why.. Recently I found myself with time on my hands, and I began to think about them. I've always written with my left hand, but about 50 years ago, when I was teaching English at Beaver College, I realized that I picked up a piece of chalk with my right hand when I was about to write on the blackboard. In recent years I've written shopping lists with my right hand because I write more clearly-albeit more slowly-with that hand. But I use my left hand for other kinds of writing, like editing something I've printed from the computer

title: Prelude to a State Pension Bailout
summary: Rescuing multiemployer plans is unwise and signals a willingness to do the same with failing state and local funds.. After decades of mismanagement, state and local government pensions face unfunded liabilities topping $4.2 trillion. When a major public plan finally runs dry, you can bet Congress will bail it out no matter the crippling cost. Congressional Democrats' Covid-relief package includes a multibillion-dollar bailout for union-affiliated private-sector multiemployer pensions. If politicians will bail out truckers' and coal miners' pensions, why would they turn away teachers and firefighters?

title: Will Maduro's Canary Sing?
summary: The dictator sweats while the U.S. seeks to extradite his indicted associate.. Some 3,500 miles from Washington, on the African archipelago of Cape Verde, the Justice Department is in a struggle with Venezuela over a U.S. extradition request for Alex Saab.

title: Nasdaq Amends Its Diversity Plan
summary: We've listened to critics and made allowances for their needs and concerns.. Nasdaq recently submitted a proposal to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission focused on diversity of the boards of companies listed on our U.S. exchange. Our proposal establishes a recommended objective for companies to include at least two board members from diverse backgrounds. We asked that each company disclose anonymous aggregate data-self-disclosed by the directors-regarding their gender identity, race, ethnicity and sexual orientation.

title: 'The Anointed' Review: Gentlemen Play a Rufﬁan's Game
summary: The clubbiness of the white-shoe law ﬁrms was an outgrowth of a social elitism that sneered at competition as unseemly.. Well-paid drones who toil into the night as associates in big law firms owe a debt of some kind to William Nelson Cromwell, an early architect of the Wall Street partnership Sullivan & Cromwell. He was fond of saying: "A successful man never forgets his work." Try telling that to your family on a Saturday night. Then there was Paul Cravath, who pretty much invented the modern law business as an assembly line for Ivy League grads grinding away at minute tasks-in Cravath's less-than-inspiring words, each "a cog in the machinery of a big law office."

title: Biden Administration Urged to Penalize Saudi Crown Prince Over Khashoggi Killing
summary: Administration stopped short of punishing Mohammed bin Salman for his alleged role in the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Democrats and a former CIA chief have criticized President Biden's decision not to directly punish Saudi Arabia's crown prince for his alleged role in the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

title: How Europe Became the World's Biggest EV Market
summary: Subsidies and more choices have helped spur consumer demand, but China serves as a warning that such momentum can be fleeting. Europe is buying electric vehicles at a record pace and has overtaken China as the world's biggest EV market, as consumers are encouraged by government subsidies and dozens of new cars and hybrids.

title: Israel to Vaccinate Palestinians Who Have Israeli Work Papers
summary: Program, approved Sunday by the nation's political leaders, will begin in the coming days. TEL AVIV-Israel will vaccinate Palestinian laborers who work in Israel and in Jewish settlements in the West Bank, Israel's military said. The move comes as Israel has faced pressure to vaccinate Palestinians who live under Israeli control.

title: Economy Week Ahead: Factories, Services and Employment
summary: U.S. jobless claims are expected to remain elevated in the week that ended Feb. 27. The Labor Department's monthly employment report highlights this week's economic data.

title: Dozens in Hong Kong's Opposition Charged Under Law Imposed by Beijing
summary: All of the political figures charged had participated in primaries held by the pro-democracy camp in July. HONG KONG-Authorities charged dozens of the city's most prominent opposition figures with national-security offenses after the political figures took part in unofficial primary elections, the largest use of the sweeping new law since it was imposed on the territory by Beijing.

title: Animals Make Corporate Zoom Calls Bearable, if You Don't Mind the Spit
summary: Resume Subscription. Dozens of people from San Francisco software company Benchling Inc. were logged into a video call featuring a special guest when the meeting quickly went off-script.

title: Covid-19 Vaccines Yield Breakthroughs in Long-Term Fight Against Infectious Disease
summary: Resume Subscription. The pandemic has opened a new era for vaccines developed with gene-based technologies, techniques that have long stumped scientists and pharmaceutical companies, suggesting the possibility of future protection against a range of infectious disease.

title: The Federal Reserve Is Financing Future Debt Problems
summary: The Fed's creative accounting combined with profligate federal spending won't end the pain for Americans.. Economists John Greenwood and Steve H. Hanke ably sound the alarm in "The Money Boom Is Already Here" (op-ed, Feb. 22). Too many have looked away as the Federal Reserve prints dollars by another name: quantitative easing. While the authors rightly describe the profound implications of the massive surge in M2 from the money that has already been spent, they neglected to mention the implications for the pending $1.9 trillion in Covid spending that President Biden and many at Treasury and the Fed have requested. Follow their logic and understand the profoundly bad implications of an additional $2 trillion on top of the $4 trillion in prior Covid-rationalized spending.

title: Trump Lost, but He Greatly Boosted the GOP
summary: Many voters came out solely for President Trump, and the down-ballot candidates on the Republican ticket reaped the rewards.. Your editorial "Trump Lost to Himself" (Feb. 19) ignores many of the facts surrounding the 2020 election and runs contrary to our firm's postelection polling and analysis. In 2020, President Trump created one of the greatest voter coalitions in American political history, bringing millions of new voters into the Republican Party and expanding the GOP's vote among African-Americans and Hispanic Americans.

title: Could Long-Covid Patients Shed Light on ME/CFS?
summary: The similarities between long-haul Covid-19 and ME/CFS are stunning.. "At Work: The Challenges of Getting Long-Covid Patients Working" (Personal Journal, Feb. 16) could have been describing sufferers of myalgic encephalomyelitis, otherwise known as chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS). The similarities between long-haul Covid-19 and ME/CFS are stunning. Perhaps the sheer volume of the cases of Covid long-haulers will shed a light on ME/CFS, which is a much-ignored condition. People with ME/CFS experience the same "crash" after a period of physical or mental exertion, as well as many of the other symptoms described in the article, and skepticism from co-workers.

title: Don't Be So Quick to Count on National Herd Immunity
summary: We need to maintain social distancing and mask wearing until the country is vaccinated.. In "We'll Have Herd Immunity by April" (op-ed, Feb. 19), Marty Makary says that the country is rapidly reaching "herd immunity" to the coronavirus. There is a simple and compelling case to be made that this isn't the case. In addition to the recent reduction in coronavirus, seasonal influenza has also shown dramatic reduction in incidence in the U.S. as well as the rest of the world. We never develop "herd immunity" to seasonal influenza, which is why we need yearly flu shots. The fact that influenza incidence has been reduced so dramatically is all because of behavior, not some new immunological phenomenon. The same is true of Covid. Behavior can explain the recent reduction given that the same reduction is also seen in an unrelated respiratory virus.

title: Lonely Boaters Passing, if Not in the Dark of Night
summary: The two rowers, Schmitt and Eakins, are rowing in opposite directions .. In John Wilmerding's excellent discussion ("Respite on The River," Masterpiece, Feb. 20) of Thomas Eakins's magnificent painting "Max Schmitt in a Single Scull," a significant detail is omitted from the analysis. The two rowers, Schmitt and Eakins, are rowing in opposite directions on the river, one upstream, the other downstream. They have passed one another and are separating, as their wakes show. Each is truly single and alone.

title: Academic Freedom Is Withering
summary: Surveys of faculty opinion show the growing extent of political discrimination and cancel culture.. Academic freedom is in crisis on American campuses. Last year, the National Association of Scholars recorded 65 instances of professors being disciplined or fired for protected speech, a fivefold increase from the year before. Yet many of academia's defenders brush aside worries about dismissal campaigns and the lack of ideological diversity as little more than a collection of anecdotes cherry-picked to feed a right-wing moral panic.

title: Earth to Techies: Let's Map It All
summary: Imaging the world down to the meter will soon spur a navigation breakthrough.. To make nuclear bombs, you float a gaseous uranium compound down long distances until molecules with the heavier U-238 isotope fall away, leaving only highly fissionable U-235. That's why during the Cold War the U.S. flew U-2 spy planes over the Soviet Union to film the ground, so that analysts with lightboards and magnifying glasses could study photos looking for long, narrow buildings. And you thought your job was tedious? We've come a long way. But that was a while ago-what's possible today?

title: Goldman Consumer Head Is Leaving to Run Walmart Fintech
summary: Omer Ismail, who helped build Goldman's consumer-banking business from scratch, will take on a similar task at Walmart. A Goldman Sachs Group Inc. executive who helped build its consumer-banking business from scratch is leaving to take on a similar task at Walmart Inc.

title: San Francisco Parents Work to Recall School Board Members
summary: Board is accused of being distracted by school-renaming efforts instead of getting students back into classrooms. SAN FRANCISCO-Fed up with the pace of plans to reopen public schools, parent groups are mobilizing against San Francisco's elected school board, arguing it has given priority to social justice issues over getting kids back in classrooms.

title: Herbalife to Name Three New Directors as Icahn Era Ends
summary: Two current Herbalife directors don't plan to stand for re-election. Herbalife Nutrition Ltd. plans to overhaul its board as Carl Icahn winds down his eight-year involvement with the company and it looks to burnish its standing with other investors.

title: Wealthy Democrat Is Targeted by Both Parties in Wisconsin Senate Race
summary: Contest for the seat of Republican Sen. Ron Johnson-who hasn't said if he's running again-is watched closely. Alex Lasry might be swimming upstream as he seeks the U.S. Senate nomination in Wisconsin from a Democratic Party skeptical of Wall Street and worried about income inequality.

title: New York City Invests in Rapid Covid-19 Test to Aid Economic Recovery
summary: Team from Columbia University is front-runner in a competition to develop an at-home antigen test. Nearly a year after Covid-19 first tore through New York, the outlook for a rebound in economic activity is partly tied to the ease and availability of testing for the disease.

title: New York Small Businesses to Get Fine Refunds Under Council Bill
summary: New legislation would ease code-violation enforcement and provide civil-penalty relief for restaurants, laundromats, other businesses. The New York City Council is considering legislation that would provide relief to small businesses, including easing code-violation enforcement and refunding thousands of fines that restaurateurs and mom-and-pop shops have been issued during the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: The Markets and Mr. Powell
summary: The 10-year Treasury resumes its rise and stocks hit the skids.. So much for Jerome Powell's reassurances. Only a day after the Federal Reserve Chairman's two-day, nothing-to-worry-about tour of Capitol Hill, financial markets suddenly found plenty to worry about on Thursday. Stocks fell sharply as the 10-year Treasury note yield had its largest one-day advance since November to its highest level in a year.

title: U.S. Seeks Allies to Counter Chinese Technology
summary: Combined efforts in semiconductors, artificial intelligence seen as way to thwart Beijing's ambitions. President Biden portrays U.S. relations with China as a clash of values: democracy vs. autocracy.

title: Geode Closes Hedge-Fund Business
summary: Geode Capital Management's largest private fund lost about $250 million as wagers on stock-market volatility turned sour last year. Huge losses on derivative trades at Geode Capital Management have forced the giant investment firm to close down its hedge-fund business.

title: Go East, Young Man: China Needs to Set its Labor Force Free
summary: To keep growth high in the years ahead, China must loosen up controls on internal migration-before it is too late. China's perennial struggle with wasteful investment is well known. Less well appreciated is the scale of wasted and frustrated talent, as government regulations have long prevented millions of workers from settling in China's biggest, most dynamic cities.

title: Macy's, Other Stores Will Let You Buy Now, Pay Later
summary: Retailers add new payment options to attract younger shoppers; 'If we didn't have it, they might have gone elsewhere'. Traditional retail chains like Macy's Inc. that derive much of their income from shoppers who pay with a store credit card are making room for a less-lucrative customer: buy now, pay later.

title: Affordable Wireless Noise-Canceling Headphones: Good Sound With a Trade-Off
summary: Four Bluetooth options from Monoprice and Anker's Soundcore brand produce decent sound-but the noise cancellation is clearly second rate. Headphones and wine have a lot in common. You can spend next to nothing or drop hundreds of dollars. And like wine, you can make a great headphone find without breaking the bank. You just have to know where to look-or whom to ask.

title: How Golden Globe Hosts Tina Fey and Amy Poehler Make Everyone Around Them Funny, Too
summary: The comedy duo returns to host the annual awards show for the fourth time-this year, remotely from separate coasts. Four of their collaborators on what makes them such skillful hosts.. When hosts Tina Fey and Amy Poehler take the stage together this Sunday to welcome the presenters and nominees to the 78th Golden Globes, there will be about 2,500 miles between them. Fey will be recorded live in New York and Poehler in California, which introduces a tricky hosting dynamic to the annual proceedings. Fey and Poehler-with three Globes under their belts already and improv skills honed from years on Saturday Night Live-are well equipped for the challenge.

title: Bond-Market Tumult Puts 'Lower for Longer' in the Crosshairs
summary: A recent wave of selling drove up the yield on the 10-year Treasury note, which helps set borrowing costs from corporate debt to mortgages, to its highest level since the pandemic began. February's government-bond rout has rattled one of the foundations of the past year's powerful stock-market rally: investor certainty that ultralow long-term interest rates are here to stay.

title: Investors Worry the Fed's Fast Driving Means It'll Have to Hit the Brakes
summary: Volatility in stock, bond markets this past week indicates inflation concerns are rising. Here are two things that are both true: A stronger economy is generally good for stocks, and a stronger economy means higher Treasury yields. Students of logic don't have to progress far in their studies to realize that higher Treasury yields are not, therefore, necessarily good for stocks, and if they missed the class they need do no more than glance at last week's markets.

title: New Chauffeur-Hailing Service Seeks to Challenge Uber, Lyft
summary: German upstart Blacklane bets on virus-conscious business traveler. BERLIN-Blacklane, an upscale ride-hailing company whose biggest investor is Daimler AG , is launching a new inner-city service in New York on Monday, seeking to challenge the black car services of rivals Uber and Lyft as the coronavirus pandemic continues to reshape the industry.

title: When Should You Think Twice About Salary Negotiation?
summary: Young workers have had it drilled into them that they should push for more pay-here's how to avoid hidden pitfalls while working to strike a deal. Kate Lindsay, a 28-year-old writer in New York, was thrilled when she was offered a staff writer position at Rolling Stone magazine's website in spring 2019. She was working at a women's media website that often covered financial advice and salary negotiation.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Is a Struggle for Those With No Hospital Connection
summary: Difficult access highlights one challenge officials face in the effort to vaccinate communities equitably. As Covid-19 vaccines continue to roll out across the country, many hospitals and clinics are giving priority to their own patients, leaving people who lack a primary-care doctor or a doctor affiliated with the right hospital struggling to find doses.

title: What Another Year of Remote Work Will Look Like
summary: Facebook considered tracking its employees. Lyft is making some workers move before April. Here's how big companies are wrestling with thorny work-from-home issues..

title: New CEO Hits Refresh at Citigroup
summary: Resume Subscription. Jane Fraser wants to simplify Citigroup Inc., the original megabank. That won't be easy.

title: Baseball's Most Expensive Traveling Show
summary: The Jays spent more on free agents this winter to bolster an exciting young lineup. Their fans love them. The only problem is they still can't play in Canada.. The Toronto Blue Jays approached prospective free agents this winter with an unusual sales pitch: We can pay you a lot of money-but we have no idea where you will live and play.

title: China Got Its Economy Growing Again, but a Shortfall in Babies Will Be Harder to Fix
summary: Some economists say a shrinking workforce threatens China's chances of overtaking the U.S. as the world's largest economy. China may have blunted the pandemic's impact on its economy, but a shortfall in babies is clouding its growth horizon.

title: Cuomo Requests Outside Review After Second Harassment Accusation
summary: Allegations come as New York governor also faces probe over nursing home Covid-19 deaths. A second former aide accused New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo of sexual harassment, prompting the governor to announce that a former federal judge would conduct an outside review.

title: J&J Covid-19 Vaccine Authorized for Use in U.S.
summary: The shot is the third cleared by U.S. Food and Drug Administration and the first requiring just one dose. The first single-dose Covid-19 vaccine, a shot from Johnson & Johnson , was authorized for use, a big boost for a mass-vaccination campaign rushing to end the deadliest pandemic in more than a century.
